Award.AwardTitle: OP: Collaborative Research: Multimodal Molecular Spectroscopy and Imaging in Biological Tissue and Historical Artwork
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, the Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Experimental Physics Program in the Division of Physics, and the Office of International Science and Engineering, Professors Martin Fischer, Warren Warren, Khanh Kieu and their groups will develop optical microscopy techniques to create high-resolution images with novel molecular and structural contrast. These imaging methods can provide detailed chemical information even below the surface and do not require the physical removal of samples to create three-dimensional maps. These techniques are ideally suited for imaging of biological tissue and historical works of art, where the removal of a sample is restricted or even impossible. Information obtained from these chemical maps can help lay the scientific foundation for the development of new methods to diagnose diseases in biological tissue and give conservators information needed to repair or even prevent damage or degradation in irreplaceable works of art.

The loss of function in biological tissue and historical artworks, such as discoloration or cracking in a painting or disease in tissue, generally is reflected in changes in the molecular composition or structure on a microscopic scale. A major challenge in diagnostic evaluation is that to obtain this information, mechanical sample removal is generally required. In response to this challenge, this research seeks to develop a multimodal detection method based on nonlinear pump-probe microscopy to noninvasively map pigments and their surroundings with high spatial resolution in three dimensions. Specifically, the techniques being developed access novel contrast mechanisms (such as nonlinear phase contrast) which give much higher specificity and a wider range of endogenous targets. Furthermore, critical degradation processes are being studied in tissue and artwork, including inherent (e.g. natural degradation) and induced (e.g. photodegradation) processes. Lastly, the team is working toward dissemination of suitable instruments using these techniques to the biomedical and conservation science communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In most deterioration processes, problems tend to get bigger, the longer one waits to address them. This applies to human diseases like skin cancer, which often can be treated effectively if it is detected early enough. The same is true for a historic painting that deteriorates, for example though pigments that fade or change color - if detected early, deterioration in many artworks may be stopped or at least slowed down to preserve the work for future generations. In this research project, we applied an optical microscopy technique, pump-probe microscopy, to identify and map pigments and their degradation products in biological tissue and historical artwork in three dimensions and at high spatial resolution.

In biological tissue, we investigated the pigment melanin as a marker for melanoma, a very aggressive form of skin cancer. In melanoma, melanin is broken down by the cancer cells and, as a result, changes its optical properties. In order to understand the process of melanin degradation and the resulting changes in melanin's optical properties, we performed studies in a simplified model of natural melanin: melanin-like nanoparticles. Unlike natural melanin, the properties of these synthetic particles can be tuned (such as their chemical composition, structure, and size), and they can be artificially degraded in a process that mimics the degradation in tissue. Using this model system, we investigated the relationship between melanin's complex assembly structure and the highly unusual, but diagnostically useful optical signatures accessible in our microscope. In cellular uptake studies, we then showed that the degradation in these particles also occurs in cancer cells, and leads to the same optical signatures. The understanding of the underlying photophysics in melanin, and using photophysical signatures to generate molecular imaging contrast in skin slides, will provide the opportunity to use our microscopy technique for the determination of the aggressiveness of a melanoma skin lesion.

In historical paintings degradation can manifest itself through a range of effects, from structural changes (like cracking or flaking) or changes in appearance (pigments can change colors, or even fade completely). These changes can occur on the surface, for example through light exposure or humidity, but they can also originate within deeper layers. The same microscopy technique we used for studying melanin is also suited to identify and map pigments in paintings. By accessing molecular contrast that is very specific to certain pigments, it can even distinguish colorants that look similar to the eye, but are chemically very different. For example, we have distinguished and mapped a range of red organic dyes commonly used in historic paintings - a task that is very difficult with established technologies. We have also been able to investigate degradation processes that are of great concern to conservators in museums worldwide. For example, we have been able to detect the degradation of vermilion, a common red organic pigment, in a 14th century painting on a microscopic scale. Most interestingly, we were able to identify regions in the painting that showed early signs of degradation, even before any deterioration was visible to the eye (or to any other analytical tool available today).

The broader impacts of the project were to make this technology more accessible to other groups and even other fields. Towards this end, we developed methods that reduce the complexity and cost of some of the key components of our microscope. We were able to use much smaller and easier-to-use laser sources, developed safer ways to illuminate the samples, and reduced the cost of detection electronics by at least an order of magnitude.

The graduate students involved in this project continued to work closely with the paintings conservators at the North Carolina Museum of Art. They also collaborated with the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC, working with several conservation scientists. The results have been presented at several national and international meetings (such as the Gordon Research Conference on Scientific Methods in Cultural Heritage Research). The investigators have also organized a two-day symposium that heavily featured the techniques developed during this work.
